newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Red Cross Federation issues new appeal for N Korea.
newsitem.headline: Red Cross Federation issues new appeal for N Korea.

text.p: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) on Thursday issued a revised appeal of nearly 26 million Swiss francs ($18 million) to expand operations for famine-threatened North Korea.
George Weber, secretary-general of the world relief body, signed the appeal at the start of a two-day meeting in Geneva with officials from 15 donor societies, including South Korea.
The IFRC, the world's largest humanitarian network which links 171 national societies, already has a programme of food aid for Pyongyang, hit by two years of devastating floods.

Its expanded operation, due to begin in July, will include food aid for more than 700,000 people, a one-year medical programme and a three-year disaster preparedness programme, according to a Federation statement.

"The expanded operation will allow a much greater number of people to receive adequate food rations until the next harvest, in late October, and will give some 2.6 million people in 19 counties access to better health care," Weber said.
Paik Yong Ho, secretary-general of the North Korean Red Cross, and Kim Heh nam, director of international relations at the South Korean Red Cross, are attending the donors' talks.
